segments.text: 270 to return for a final pass.
This time down the original line of aircraft on my first pass.
With more time and better light, I could do a better job.
A larger-sized Jap plane stood out from the others.
Looked like a recce plane, perhaps.
A what kind?
Recce.
Reconnaissance.
Oh, okay.
I settled on it as my primary and let go.
It seemed to shake itself to pieces right in front of me as I bored down a point.
With inches to spare, I pulled off and raked subsequent aircraft with my fire.
God only knows how many aircraft were damaged or destroyed in that one pass.
I don't know.
I just said...
Only seven or eight minutes at the most had passed, and I recall seeing only one P-40, Bartlington.
As I banked again, I caught a glimpse of three aircraft to my upper right.
I choked.
Were they Japs?
Nope.
Three P-40s pulling off the attack.
It's amazing to think back how without any specific detailed pre-planning that experienced people
knowing what they do, just start and stop something in such coordination as this.
It's just unbelievable, but that's the way it happened.
And so your three colleagues were up above, and they were fleeing.
Yeah.
Oh, yeah.
It's time to get out of there.
To hell with pushing my luck.
I backed up and pulled up to join them.
And now we were on our way back home.
I looked back at the field as I rounded the southwest corner of the mountain and did my heart good.
What satisfaction.
This is what I said to myself.
That's for Mogwe and old Swartz, you bastards.
Swartz was a pilot that was caught in a bomber attack at Mogwe and killed on the ground.
These successive passes and resulting destruction in that 10 to 12 minutes of aerial attack with nothing but fighter high caliber gunfire are too much to describe completely.
The entire airfield seemed to be in flames the last time I saw it as we headed northwest back to Burma.
As we learned later, the entire Japanese Southeast Asian Air Force was out of action for a good two weeks.
We had apparently caught them as they amassed a major concentration of aircraft just before making a big strike against us in China.
and see the old man this way he planned it.
Sure.
Great planning.
At that time, however, my only thoughts were centered on pride of a mission accomplished exactly according to plan, to Chennault's plan.
So then you continued back.
Can I get you now?
So you continued back.
How proud he would be.
Hell, I was.
Yeah.
I learned later Bob Neal and Pepper Gornian had made several scraping passes and retired also.
Ed Rector and McGarry, they were at the top, the top cover, and they were coming back also.
So all six of you are going back now?
Now, all six of us are on our way back.
And the four of us were together, I think, going back.
And Bob Neal somehow and one of the other guys got off.
with two aircraft.
But I remember only four of us together because Blackback McGarry was in my flight, and I noticed he began to trail back.
And our little radio wouldn't work.
He couldn't depend on it.
Couldn't talk to him.
So I started circling real slow and to turn back, let him catch up.
And he kept going straight forward.
wouldn't turn to go with us.
And I knew, he knew where we were going, and he was trying to get there, but something was wrong.
Because by dawn on me, he was in trouble.
And pretty soon, sure enough, I slowed down and started circling around him with the other guy.
And pretty soon, black smoke started coming out of his airplane.
I knew he was in trouble, and he started losing altitude.
And he was going to slow, but we had to put our flaps down in front of him to stay with him.
And I think I remember trying then to talk to him on the radio, but never could get him.
And I flew up close enough to him where his
his canopy was open and smoke was blowing out of the side of his airplane.
And he was getting lower and lower.
And I could tell, you know, he'd left for a place to land.
This was jungle, hill.
And we hadn't quite got to the, I think it's the Salween River that separates the two countries from Thailand.
And I held up a map.
I figured something was going to happen.
I held up a map to show it to him that, you know, I was,
Robert, let him know that I had a map I'd get to him.
I don't know why I did it, but I just held up a map and waved to him.
And he'd look at me every once in a while.
And I'd see him every few seconds.
Then he'd look back at me.
And finally, all of a sudden, his airplane just, he just rolled his airplane over like that.
And he fell out.
He was bailing out.
Oh, so he rolled his airplane over upside down.
To get out.
To bail out.
He was doing bail out.
He knew something.
He couldn't land.
He had to bail out.
Obviously, his airplane was.
He knew it was gone.
Yeah.
So he had to get out.
And when he bailed out, then I started circling to show his chute open.
And I saw him hit the ground, but in the trees, or some of those trees, I was 200 feet from him.
But at any rate, I shoot.
His chute did open.
Oh, yeah.
And he floated down.
And subsequently, well, I spoke to him.
He was captured as a prisoner.
He was captured by the Japanese then?
Yeah.
He was just about two or three miles short of that river he'd been in.
And I flew over there and dropped my map over it.
I don't know.
I doubt if he ever found it.
I never did ask him.
But then, you know, we're getting old guys.
So I said, well, we're old black men.
So I wiggled for the other guys.
What happened to him?
He was captured by the Japs and held prisoner of war until the end of the war.
And I saw him at a reunion we had yesterday.
Oh, back in the early 70s, and old Black Mac had gone through a rough time.
As a matter of fact, he was a little off his rocker, but he was all right.
And he never did talk much about it, but apparently it was a shock to him.
Anyway, I don't know where he is now.
Okay, so that's what happened to one of them.
That gives you five planes.
Yeah.
So we went on and recovered at Namsan.
Now, we were reasonably sure that there wasn't going to be any airplane that got off that air base to follow us up, you know, and attack us while we were refueling.
Five of you landed.
Well, yes.
Five, right.
Actually, we anticipated nine.
New Kirk flight, I haven't even talked about it yet.
Anticipated seven.
You anticipated seven.
I anticipated four.
I anticipated a total of nine airplanes.
See, ten of us took off.
Okay, so you're right.
Nine.
Nine.
Okay.
In other words, we expected nine aircraft to recover at the damn time.
We've got to have to get those damn things refueled and get them off of there.
Yeah.
Okay.
But where were the other four going?
Well, I'll tell you that.
Okay, you're going to tell me.
Okay.
Well, we landed.
And I explained to Bob Neal what had happened to Black Mac McGarry.
And we discussed this thing.
And then here come three other airplanes out of the other four, Newkirk's flight.
They come in.
And we said, where's Newkirk?
And then they told the story.
Well, part of the plan with Newkirk was to take off the same time we did, 10 airplanes that morning,
All of us were supposed to run and go over the field at 10,000 feet.
For some reason or other, Newkirk never did even go to 10,000 feet with his three other airplanes.
But his mission was to hit another air base.
He was supposed to hit one.
Now, Newkirk's flight was supposed to attack an air base at...
Lam Lung, L-A-M-B-L-U-N-G, which was another Japanese air base just south of Chiang Mai, about 20 miles.
It so happened that Newkirk, for some reason or another, remember I told you he was very depressed and sad, he and his three remaining guys never could explain it.
He just said that they took off, and he never did climb at 10,000 feet, but he immediately took off on a course
down the railroad, which passed Chiang Mai, Thailand, about two or three miles, three or four miles to the east of the field.
And he stayed right on that railroad at low altitude.
And that, he got there a little bit ahead of us, see, having started at low altitude, and we climbed at 10,000 feet and crewed down, so we were a little behind him.
So that explained why Japanese were getting into their airplanes, were actually in their airplanes with the props turning,
Because when his flight passed over the depot near the city, that got the alert to the air base, and they at least had that alert.
But fortunately, we got there in time before they could do anything else.
Because just as they were getting in airplanes, and now they saw we were hitting them, so they started running for cover.
And he went on down, and strafing, by the way, down the railroad track.
He went on down to Lam Lung, and there wasn't a single thing at that air base.
So they turned around, coming back, strafing that, you know, targets of opportunity that came back.
Of course, it's daylight now.
And they said when we passed by the depot again at Chiang Mai, we could look up and say there was no doubt where Chiang Mai Air Base was.
Said there was nothing but just a mass of black smoke over there in the air, up going over 10,000, 15,000.
And
It was along there that they said Newkirk made a dive on what appeared to be an armed vehicle, an armed personnel carrier, that type of thing.
They had a gun, a heavy caliber gun.
It wasn't a tank.
But he said as he dove on it, this heavy caliber gun shot.
And evidently, whatever it was, caught his airplane, smacked down, and he just went right on in.
Killed him to death.
That's what happened to Jack Newcoat.
The other three came on back and then they recovered at the same place as them saying, right after we did, and that's where then we got the story.
So all of us refueled and then went on over to the lower wing.
Okay, well this guy then almost sabotaged your mission.
That's right.
We don't know if he did it because he was shaken up because of, you know,
not being given command of the thing.
I've heard stories from some of his squadron that actually Jack Newkirk was the boy that dreamed up the mission and got Jonathan Ault to prove it.
And if that's the case, then he had more right to be shaken up and felt bad about the old man giving it to Bob Neal.
But nevertheless, he disobeyed orders.
Well, he disobeyed orders, or for some reason or another, unknowing to us, he couldn't comply with it.
But anyway, he didn't do what he was supposed to do.
And actually, we couldn't wait on him.
That could have jeopardized your life.
It could have jeopardized my life.
If that explains why those Japanese polished me in those airplanes.
See, they already had their props turning, and they were getting ready to taxi.
We caught them just in time.
You caught them in time.
Now, did the other three that Newkirk was with, when Newkirk went in to hit the base, did the other three follow?
Oh, the other, they stayed.
You know, there's a formation of attack.
Did they attack also?
They stayed together.
Huh?
Did they also attack the air base?
There was nothing on the air base at Lam Long.
No, I mean when they came back over the one that you hit.
No, they didn't come over our base.
They just come down the railroad and pass the railroad station about three or four miles, which they went by before.
And this time there was a gun on it, though.
Well, obviously, you know, the whole city had been alerted, and the Army, Japanese Army, as well as the Air Force was alerted.
And it probably was an armed personnel carrier that was, you know, alerted and ready, too.
In other words, taking on the conformation of Air Defense.
But it was a heavy-caliber gun.
And it just so happened that they caught him.
And I don't know if Kirk was a terrific boy.
He had 10 or 12 of his credit at that time.
OK, so you got back after the raid.
This is the 25th of March, which in all sense
Oh, he was absolutely delighted and elated.
And as a matter of fact, even the Japanese Air Force acknowledged an attack by the Flying Tiger Demon or something, whatever it was.
But they had never admitted all their losses.
We figured, in my opinion,
We had to have destroyed at least 40 aircraft.
There's no way possible there couldn't have been these 40 aircraft destroyed.
And I think we got credit for 10, or paid for 10, divided amongst us.
Sure, right.
So that's how you got two and a quarter more.
Yeah.
So that gives you your total.
I ended up with nine and a quarter, however it comes out, Terry.
It's on my discharge.
That's what I was paid for.
Well, okay, let's continue.
You were back up in Kunming.
Well, then, of course, we eventually went back to Kunming.
Yeah, okay.
And you stayed there doing what?
And followed the same type of life for a while, you know, staying on alert and wondering how we could get into combat.
By this time, you can imagine how we had stung the Japanese Air Force.
They were just, you know, they were leery of us.
We hadn't destroyed these flying Tiger Demons yet.
And here's four airplanes made this attack.
more fighters.
So you can imagine how shaken up they were.
Well, so we figured it, figured it, figured ways to do it, and no way.
And then, by the way, this was a period of where no combat, that, you know, our morale, we began to wonder, you know, why stay over here any longer?
And, you know, idle.
So it, our morale wasn't too hot.
And the Japanese was pushing on up into northern Burma and nibbling at the southern border of Yan'an province of China and making raids on southern China.
So the old man decided, well, give some action.
He called Bob Neill in and told him to take, I believe they were, I'll have to refer to my diary again,
I was one of the guys to go on this one, too.
I was always, you know, I was number two in command.
Bob and I developed a very close rapport and mutual respect.
Wherever he went, I went.
So, I went down on this one, and we went to a place in the south, in the extreme southwestern corner of China, just north of the Burma border called Paoshan, P-A-O-S-H-A-N.
First time that I got in combat when I was shot down.
Okay, this is May 4th.
So you sat around there for a month and a half, and finally it's May 4th, 1942.
Okay, so tell me about this mission, May 4th, 1942.
We had just returned from a sort of a patrol flight in northern Burma.
And Bob Neal had caught a Japanese observation plane at so altitude, it was like shooting ducks out of the air and shot him down.
And I kid him when we got back that he ought to have been shaming himself, catching the poor boy like that, stepping up on him.
But when we got back- Did he even have any guns on him, an observation plane?
Well, whether he had any guns or not, I don't know.
But I know he never even knew Bob was on him.
It was about 1,000 feet in the air, and Bob hit him.
He just went straight in.
Then we settled down.
I started cleaning my pistol.
Didn't have anything to do.
We were on a standing alert.
I started cleaning my pistol.
We heard some noises overhead, went outside the alert track to find two Japanese wreckage ships high overhead.
Bartling and I took off in hopes of catching them.
By the time we got to 80,000 feet, they were gone.
On the way to recover at the field, I heard Bob Neal on the radio, and I knew he was already back from Kunming near Paoshan.
In a few minutes, Bob and Mickey showed up over the field.
Apparently, Mickey was okay enough to return to the field.
Bob Neal, Bob Little, one of the aces of the Flying Tigers, killed about two months after that, by the way.
and I was still involved in cleaning our pistols when Neil yelled for us to man our ships.
We dashed out to the plains, and by the time I had started my engine, I looked up and saw the Jap bomber formation high above and heading toward our field.
It looked like about 25 bombers and about 18,000 feet.
Neil started shooting his pistol in the air to get everyone's attention and started running for the ditch immediately behind our parking area.
My engine had warmed up.
I sat there in the cockpit with my hand on the throttle and paused for a second.
Hell, I can make it, I thought.
I shoved the throttle open and headed straight across the field.
I had not gotten into my parachute or put my helmet on.
I was just sitting in the cockpit.
I didn't even have my seatbelt on yet, and my canter was still open.
The only thought entering my mind was to get airborne and beyond the edge of the field before the bombs hit.
My speed built up unusually slow, and suddenly my tail literally jumped off the ground.
Damn, I had not even put up my flaps, which was pre-takeoff procedure.
I had quite a lot of field yet, so I put them up.
I leaped forward and just did manage to clear the rock barricade at the far end of the field.
I turned to the left and started getting into my gear as I started a maximum climb.
I could see the bomber formation clearly now.
They skipped the field and were bombing the city.
I wasn't climbing nearly as fast as I expected.
Something was wrong.
I had full throttle and RPM.
Oh, hell, I forgot my landing gear and all the haste and excitement.
I got up and then started gaining on the bomber formations.
They were now in a wide sweeping turn to head back south after dropping their bomb.
I cut across and pulled up in a steeper climb.
In the meantime, I stole a quick look at the city below.
The bombing was almost perfect, right in the middle of the city.
Those yellow bastards, I thought.
I looked around for possible enemy fighter escort and saw none, but I did pick up the second wave of about the same number of bombers.
So how many bombers were there?
Fifty.
Fifty bombers?
Fifty or fifty-four, I'll give you a question.
Two big formats.
My goodness.
I had a better chance against them since they were treading the first enemy waves, so I positioned myself to concentrate on them.
This is approximate.
I was the only one there.
You were the only one?
Yeah.
See, I really violated orders.
Bob Neal told us all to get in the ditch.
It's too late.
So I took off.
Thinking, you know, I... And that's the reason I forgot so many things.
They were at 18,000 feet and a single, huge V formation, very tight.
I got about 1,000 feet above and off to the right.
I made a diving left turn and pulled up into the right rear quarter of the outside flank of the formation.
I closed in on the flank bomber and squeezed the trigger.
My burst completely enveloped the fuselage, but I saw no smoke or fire.
The two adjacent bombers immediately started streaming a bluish-white smoke.
I knew I hadn't hit them.
They were pulling the old trick of releasing smoke to attract me to them as wounded aircraft.
We had been briefed on this trick, but this was the first time I'd seen it.
I wasn't about to take that bait.
The bomber on the extreme flank end pulled away a bit, and this made it even more obvious.
I continued my rear right quarter attacks at it first, and on my third attack, I saw his right engine disintegrate and ignite into a flaming torch.
He went down through the overcast.
I continued on the next bomber on the tail of the V.
Is this too detailed?
No.
Suddenly my guns quit firing.
I had become too engrossed in my attacks.
I had obviously been firing long, by far too long bursts.
Recharging guns produced no results.
I had to be out of ammunition.
I pulled away sharply, and then diving, 180 screen, 180 return to head back.
I had to run out of ammo.
I told you before I wasn't a good gunner.
Now where am I?
I had chased some 50 enemy bombers down across northern Burma and only gotten one.
I was downright disappointed in myself.
Also, in my gunnery, I had them all to myself, and there were no enemy fighter escort whatsoever.
But there was nothing to do now but get back to Palashan.
How far were you?
I mean, about how many miles were you from the air base now to get back to land?
Let me see if I see.
I spied the Burma Road bridge over the Salarain River and felt better about my position.
I knew where I was now and I had a sufficient field over an action chain before I slided head-directed to the field.
I couldn't have been more than sixty or seventy miles, maybe eighty or seventy miles south of the field.
I had begun to recount everything I had done on the flight and furthered
my remorse that I didn't get more jets.
Soon the field appeared up ahead, and as I got closer in, I tried to pick up our ground station on the radio.
Several calls brought no reply, and I was now in a steep dive toward the field.
I leveled out and did a slow roll as I crossed over the alert area.
I tried the radio again with the same results and decided that they were probably in the ditches.
I thought I'd make a wide turn around the city and spread out my traffic pattern to examine the bomb damage in the city.
What a sight.
The city had been spilling over with evacuees, and they were jammed throughout the place.
The Japanese bombs had caught them without any warning.
Fire seemed to be engulfing the entire city, and I could see many buildings and houses blown to bits.
My approach to the field took me squarely over the middle of the city, and after one last look, I concentrated on the landing approach and slowed down to get my flaps and landing gear down.
I had just moved the gear lever forward when I heard several loud explosions.
The noise stunned me for a second, and I immediately concluded that my landing gear hydraulic system had blown up.
I had been having trouble with my gear operating correctly the last several days, but I never really found anything wrong with it.
I decided to try to recycle the gear lever, and when I reached down, I cried out in pain.
I had stuck my left hand with no gloves on in a raging fire.
I unconsciously swung my head around and looked to my rear.
There they were, three Jap Zeros right on my tail and firing like mad at me.
The explosions were explosive rounds of ammo hitting the armor plate behind my seat.
The bullets had gone through my fuselage tank, but still had a few gallons of fuel in it before impacting the armor plate.
The fuselage tank had also exploded, and the fire was whipping into my lower rear cockpit and then up around my lower body.
What a stoop I had been.
I had become so engrossed with the bombing scene below that I had made that fatal mistake that a fighter pilot should never get caught doing.
I hadn't suspected enemy fighters in the area.
Incidentally, looking back now, that was exactly the way they had planned it.
They had expected all of us to get off, and they'd catch all of us just landing without any fuel, and then they'd just annihilate us.
The Japs had laid this attack on a little different.
They knew our situation perfectly from the two recce flights that had just preceded the bombers.
They decided to forego the fighters as an escort and hold them off and away from the field with the idea of catching all of us when we returned to the field.
low on ammunition and gas, and that is exactly how they caught me.
For a split second, I think I actually was on the verge of giving up.
That's true.
I remember it very vividly.
But the old human mind and body being what it is would not let me.
I recall very vividly this day that I am touching this experience, that I leaned forward as far as my seatbelt would permit, closed my eyes because the fire had begun to completely engulf me,
reached over with my right hand to grasp the canopy crank and rolled it fully back.
Unhooked my seat belt with my left hand and then put both hands on the stick and went through the motion of what I knew would make the ship climb abruptly and roll over one half turn to the right.
How high were you?
How was your altitude?
I was on my approach about ready to flare out on the landing.
I'd say...
300 feet above the ground, 200 feet.
So you needed more altitude before you jumped.
Right.
So I climbed up.
See, when I pulled a stick up, I figured I'd climb a little and just pause a few seconds to get some altitude.
In other words, I was doing like this.
I was going to do like this.
Sure.
And then fall out.
And that's the maneuver I went through.
would make the ship climb abruptly and roll over one half turn to the right.
Then I took my hand off the control column and reached for the right side of the cockpit to get out of the seat.
The step between grabbed me as the upper part of my body protruded outside of the cockpit.
It literally dragged me out of the cockpit.
I had forgotten my earphone connection to the radio plug, but the force of the wind tore it loose.
I knew I was out of the airplane, and I opened my eyes.
One minute I would see the blue sky, and the next I would see the ground.
I realized I was tumbling.
I looked down to find a metal ring to pull my parachute, jerked it wildly.
I immediately felt it tugging and then a violent jerk.
I was sitting in a parachute strap and floating down the earth.
Suddenly I became terrified.
Those dirty yellow sons of bitches will scrape me like they did at Rangoon.
Automatically I started praying.
And I mean this.
I started praying.
Now, about how high were you at this time after you jumped?
How was your altitude here?
And I must have been doing it aloud because I can remember it so vividly.
I prayed devoutly to God.
I was doing it with my eyes closed.
I opened my eyes to look for the zebras, and it was like I suppose heaven would be.
They had pulled away and were heading southward.
Looking down, I saw the ground rushing up at me, and I knew it would hit backwards if I didn't do something.
To answer your question, I couldn't have been.
Well, they told me later on from the ground.
I probably fell out of the airplane 500 feet.
So the parachute probably opened about 200 feet.
I wasn't, it wasn't very long I had my feet on the ground after it opened.
And that's probably one reason they didn't break me, they didn't have time to get back up.
I tried to kick around my harness and I did get about halfway around when I hit.
I fell across some large sun-dried clouds of earth in a rice paddy.
The parachute gradually floated to the ground beside me as I tumbled a few times across the ground.
I sat up and realized I still had the grip cord and metal ring in my right hand.
Looking back now, it must have been in an iron grip.
I have it in my memo right now.
Unusual to ever do that.
Usually drop it.
I came to my senses and punched a quick release on the parachute hornet.
The strap fell away and I got up to run to a nearby knoll as a barrier to a possible strafing run by a lone Japanese fighter.
I squatted there watching the remaining Japanese fighters make strafing passes on the field.
I didn't realize it at the time, but I was
squatting behind a traditional Chinese burial mound of earth in the cemetery.
I had come down in a Chinese cemetery about a mile from the landing field.
Out of nowhere came a P-40 right on the tail of a Japanese as both of them went directly across the field in what was obviously a Jap strafing attack.
It was, I learned later, old Bob Little, who had gotten into the air after the bombers had dropped their bombs.
See, he knew I'd be coming back.
I felt a burning sensation about my neck and shoulders and suddenly realized that my scarf and flying suit must be on fire.
It happened that a small stream was flowing through the cemetery where I was crouched, so I laid down and watered in the water on my back.
My head was hurting and I unconsciously reached up to rub it.
I felt something wet and threw my hand away to look at it.
It was blood.
Jesus Christ.
I looked at my hands.
They had been badly burned and the skin had already been torn loose in several areas.
Blisters were forming.
My face and neck and upper shoulder were scorched, and in some cases erupting in blisters.
My eyebrows were gone.
Pain began to set in.
There were many Chinese natives in the cemetery crashing behind a burial hill, just as I was.
I motioned for one of them to come over to me.
He racked warily, but did start walking slowly toward me.
He had one hand behind his back.
I went through the gestures of picking up a telephone and calling someone and uttered the usual Chinese greeting, wah, wah, wah, wah, wah.
I did not have my flying jacket on, the back of which was sewn the Chinese-American flag and directly written in Chinese to help us.
But somehow he must have gotten a message, for he smiled lightly and brought his hand from behind his back to reveal a large rock.
He was ready to give me the word, thinking I was the enemy.
He motioned for me to follow him and led me off to a cluster of huts.
We entered one, and a group of Chinese peasants looked at me with no signs of any kind of emotion.
And they can do that.
But there was a telephone.
Somehow I got them to understand the words of my American doctor.
We had a doc down there, by the way.
It's amazing what sign language can do between human beings in an emergency.
I didn't talk to anyone on the phone, but one Chinese was on it continually, and I can only assume that the word got back to our AVG hospital.
Old Doc Richards appeared in the doorway all of a sudden.
I will never forget that moment.
The agony of my burns led me on the verge of passing out.
I honestly wanted to die to get out of the pain.
I would lie down, get up, walk around, lie down, get up, hold my hands up in the air to reduce the circulation of throbbing pain.
Cry out aloud and pray.
They took my clothes off, all except my shorts.
My helmet revealed two longitudinal tears, and I remember examining it.
Apparently the armor plate and the P-40 was tapered off at the top to resemble the marrying head on the shoulders of a man.
Had barely kept all but a couple of bullets from hitting me, otherwise I would have been killed.
Two bullets had barely missed the armor plate, but just enough to still rip past my head, close enough to scar my scalp and bring blood.
I still have some of those shrapnel bits in my scalp now, about the size of pinheads.
Doc greeted me as he would his son.
I practically fell in his arms with only one plea.
Get me out of this pain.
He went right to work.
My head was not too bad, this small lesion from the grazing bullets.
My eyelashes and eyebrows were gone.
My face was blistered slightly on the left side, clearly outlying the bit of my helmet strapped across my face.
Around the hairline of my neck was an open wound of burnt flesh where the helmet connection plugged to my aircraft radio
dug into my flesh when I forgot to unhook it upon bailing out.
My shoulder blades were heavily blistered, and one blister ran down the middle of my back some six or eight inches.
My right thumb was blistered, but my whole left hand looked terrible, a third-degree burn.
I never saw my plane hit the ground.
Peden, a mechanic on the ground, said he had hit and bounced for 100 yards or so and then lined up in a ball of fire.
Top Rich and Bob Neal both had fired their pistols at me, trying to get my attention, but zeroes were on the table.
I learned from them that they were actually firing at me through a good 270 degrees on my turn over the city.
Prior to rolling out on my approach to the field, they never did hit me until I straightened up.
Doc gave me a shot in the arm, a couple of capsules or something, and then sat for a minute or so to let the stuff set in.
Then he started pulling the skin off the blister.
He looked at the U.S. Army Air Corps ring on my left hand and said that it had to come off.
I just peered back at the dope again and grabbed me.
Even then, though, when he pulled the ring off with the burned flesh with it, I nearly hit the ceiling.
To top that off, he started pouring peroxide on the open wall places.
I guess it was on the verge of minor conversion, but fortunately the dope took hold.
Somehow I felt glad that he was doing whatever he was.
Is this getting that?
Am I too fast?
No.
He smeared gentian violet all over the upper part of my body and very heavily over the burned portions.
I rapidly became a gooey mess.
He asked me if I could walk, and I replied that I could.
My socks were wet, and I had lost my boots.
A Chinese lady furnished me with a pair of sneakers, and we left for the jeeps outside.
My flying suit had been tied at the waistline to keep it off my burns and the upper part of my body.
On the way through the rice paddy to the jeeps, Bob Neal came up and told Doc Richards that Benny Fauch was in a bad way from bomb shrapnel.
A Chinese doctor had wanted to amputate one of Benny's legs.
He was one of our pilots.
But he would not have it and kept yelling for Dr. Rich.
I heard the doctor go on and take care of Benny and that I was okay now.
We met Bob Little at the junction with the main city road and we joked about the whole deal.
I had gotten one and he hadn't gotten any.
By now, the dope had taken over and I could feel nothing.
Hence, Denny Bob Foshay died.
Bob Neal and Bob Little
A Chinese interpreter and I clambered aboard another jeep and struck out through the city for the hospital.
Well, we drove through the city, and I remember the, well, I saw one body with no leg, arms, or head, another with his skull half gone.
Once Bob Little had to get out of the jeep to move a large timber from our path.
When he heaved to the side, a human head rolled across the road.
The air was filled with the smell of burning flesh, and if you have once smelled this odor, you will never forget it.
One very pitiful sight was a wedding Chinese mother in the middle of the road on her knees with a dead child in her arms and her equally stricken husband at her side.
Had I not been under the influence of dope, I'm sure it would have hooked Chuck right there.
At times, I thought Neil and Little both would vomit.
None of us ever said a word to each other during that entire tip.
We learned it before she had died.
About 30 minutes after arriving at the hospital, we had another scare.
And all of a sudden, me and my dragon cover all ran into the ditches.
Doc gave me some sleeping pills.
Thank God I was still alive.
And they done a blister pack and went to sleep.
And that was the end of the 4th of May.
What a day.
I don't know if you can still see the scar right there.
Is that one of the hair on it?
Subsequent to this, of course, we lost all the other airplanes on the ground.
How many were there on the ground?
I think we had six.
Bob Little got off with one, so the four airplanes were lost.
I think we later on recovered one or two of those.
Did Little lose his plane?
No, no.
He got back in all right.
And this is part of the story on the return that I want to tell you about.
It's rather interesting.
We had to get out of there right away.
It was a fun day because we were afraid he'd come back over here and catch us.
They were determined to knock us out.
They were doing a good job so far.

so the next day we had a uh paul shan paul shan the next day on may the fifth uh we uh had a the youngest the the united states army air corps air transport command had begun to come in there and there was a gooney bird c40 a c uh dc3 type that uh one of the pilots uh uh from texas i'm kidding was coming there to pick us up so we got as much uh
salvaged out of the airplane if we could.
The airmen did, like 50 calibers, you know, took them out of the airplane, and threw them all in the back of this airplane, and we're going to evacuate the place.
And Benny Fauch's body actually was still limp.
We put it, the doc put it right in the entrance of the airplane and laid it up against the back wall of the thing, and then covered him with a blanket.
He was just sitting there.
cover him with a blanket.
Of course, I was still down my waist with the cover on.
Bob Neal got on.
And Bob Little was going to take his good airplane.
He got refueling on.
He was going to stay with us, escort us, at least escort this airplane, back over up to Kunming.
That was a distance of some maybe an hour and 20-minute flight.
And we wanted to get out of there as soon as we could.
So in our haste and all, everybody got on the airplane.
The vice commander of the American Voluntary Group, we called him the vice commander, he was sort of an administrator, a guy by the name of Happy Greenlaw.
He was the husband of the gal who wrote The Tiger and the Lady, Olga Greenlaw.
And she was supposedly the historian of the ABG, and she didn't give her anything to get a hold of this.
He gave me a great big slug of Johnny Walker Red Label.
Every few seconds and a few minutes on the airplane on the way up, he'd give me another slug.
And by the time we got up to Kunming, I was about half tight.
But the gentian violet, you may have seen it sad, but to put on for burns in Notre Dame, I smeared with it.
How do you spell it?
G-E-N-T-I-A-N, velvet.
It's very good for burns.
It's a gelatin type stuff.
And once you get it on you, you have to let it wear off.
There's no way to clean it off.
It turned to purple.
So for a long, long time, they called me Deep Purple in the deployment.
But on the way up, we took off.
Bob Little was escorting us.
Next thing we know, we got up to what I assume was a cruising altitude above the mountain, like 6,000 or 8,000 feet.
And I looked out the window, and here's Bob Neal and his P-40 round the wing of this airplane, just violently wiggling his wings, you know, and waving his hands.
I told Bob, I said, what time is Bob Little?
He looked out there.
He went up to the front of the airplane and told Tex, whatever his name was.
Told the pilot.
Yeah, told the pilot to look over there and couldn't communicate.
And Bob Little kept doing like that.
And finally, Bob Neal says, well, what's he doing?
He says, what do you want us to turn around for?
He says, we're going to Kunming, aren't we?
The pilot looked at him and said, no, we're not going to Kunming, we're going to, uh, Dinjian, India.
And Bob said, you turn this thing around, we're going to Kunming.
The guy had, for some reason or another, he was returning to India over the hump, which had been about a three hour flight.
So he got him turned around and we proceeded on up to Kunming.
So it hadn't been for not old, had it not been for Bob Little, we, uh... You would have gone to India.
Yeah.
Well, I wanted to tell you that.
And then we got to Harrison Holt Medicine, of course, and he was very concerned about me, and that's how I was.
How long did it take before your condition improved?
They immediately put me in the hospital, and I stayed in the hospital.
We had two nurses very fondly.
Were they American or Chinese?
American.
Joe...
So you were in the hospital for how long?
I stayed in the hospital about
Just about two weeks.
And then I went back over the house and recuperated a few days, going to Charlie.
Thereafter, we went back in the P-40 and we were hit.
So it was about three weeks before you were back in the airplanes.
Yeah.
As a matter of fact, I think it was in April, we headed for Chongqing for some more episodes down in Kuala Lumpur.
OK. We're already in Maine here.
Kunming.
We went to Chongqing, north of Kunming.
And then later on, we're going to fly from Chongqing down to Kualian.
No, but you said April.
Well, see, this happened in May.
I'm sorry, May.
June.
In June, we went to Chongqing.
24th of May.
June.
24th of May.
Oh, okay.
We went to Chongqing, China, 24th of May.
And what was your mission down there?
Well, there again, the Japanese had been bombing Chongqing.
They didn't have any air defense.
They didn't have any air force.
So we were going to do Chongqing.
Oh, there it is.
Okay.
So it's north.
Yeah.
And now that
the nationalist capital of China.
We, again, we were going to, matter of fact, we, by that time, we had the three squadrons practically together at Kunming.
What had left?
What was left of your original 70 planes or so?
What was left?
Oh, no, I'd say we had...
But originally you had about 70, so what was left?
I'd say we had about...
Oh, yeah, we started getting some P-40Es back.
I mean, the Air Force started sending us some P-40Es.
I think two or three of the pilots had been over in India and buried in about five P-40Es, newer type aircraft.
We must have had at least 45, 50 or so, at least.
And most of them were concentrated in Kunming.
So your squadron is up at Chongqing?
Our squadron and part of another squadron was to take off and make a mass flight to Chongqing.
And the idea was, again, a little bit of vocal intelligence or psychological tactic.
As I say, the Japs had been hitting Chongqing freely.
And to get in the water some way would at least defend against it.
And also at this time, it was obvious the Japanese were going to redirect their effort to get taken over China from the coast and the west and the east, rather than up through Burma.
They had sort of given up the idea of coming up through Burma.
Logistically, it was almost impossible.
So the old man sent, I think it was about 24 airplanes, two of them, about 12 in each, something like that.
And we flew up to Chongqing.
and would make a pass around over the city and come back, fly way out from the city.
Then we'd come back and fly over the city again and make it look like, you know, maybe in a different formation, something like that.
Make it look like an awful lot of P-40s had come into Chongqing because we knew damn well there was a lot of spies, you know, Japanese in the city.
Then we went on out and landed at the field.
Well, actually, they quit bombing Chongqing.
Well, after we got there, the bombers came out.
So the word got back to you?
Oh yeah.
And then we stayed there for a while and there's really no episodes there worth mentioning, except we did go on alert.
What was the Capitol like?
It took about two hours to drive along the tortuous country roads and over the mountains, into the Capitol proper.
And I went in only a couple of times.

And I think when they're getting paid, the headquarters of the CAMCOR, Central Aircraft Manufacturing Company, which paid us, was in the capital, you know, where the Lend-Lease arrangement and everything was made.
Were there more Americans in there?
We had two of our liaison boys assigned there.
Jim Cross, one of the buddies that went over with us, he asked for it.
